Location:
El Paso, El Paso County, Texas, U.S. – Ciudad 
Juárez, Chihuahua, MX
Description: DATA FOR THE TWO FREIGHT RAILROAD BRIDGES IN THE EL PASO REGION are reported together. BNSF reports that over two-thirds of northbound trains at this port of entry use its bridge. The BNSF Railway El Paso Bridge is owned by BNSF Railway and only handles its railcars. The Mexican side of the bridge is owned by the Government of Mexico and operated by Ferromex. The Union Pacific El Paso Bridge is owned by Union Pacific Railroad and only handles its railcars. Likewise, the Mexican portion of the bridge is owned by the Government of Mexico and operated by Ferromex.
MexicanOperator: Ferromex
RailroadConnection-to-MajorCities:
BNSF IN THE U.S.: Albuquerque, New Mexico
UNION PACIFIC IN THE U.S.: Tucson, Arizona; Topeka, Kansas; Fort Worth, Texas; San Antonio, Texas
FERROMEX IN MEXICO: Ciudad Chihuahua, Chihuahua

Location:
El Paso, El Paso County, Texas, U.S. – Ciudad 
Juárez, Chihuahua, MX
AlternateNames: Santa Fe Street Bridge | Puente Benito Juárez | Puente Paso del Norte | Puente Juárez-Santa Fe |Puente Internacional Paso del Norte | Puente de la Calle Santa Fe | Puente Juárez-Santa Fe
Description: PASO DEL NORTE BRIDGE WAS ORIGINALLY BUILT IN THE 1800s. The bridge was rebuilt and opened to traffic in 1967. It is 982 feet long with four northbound lanes and a bi-directional pedestrian walkway. The U.S. side is owned and operated by the City of El Paso. The Mexican side is owned by the Government of Mexico and operated by Fideicomiso de Puentes Fronterizos de Chihuahua.
MexicanOperator: Fideicomiso de Puentes Fronterizos de Chihuahua
Connection-to-Major-Highways-US: El Paso Street, which provides access to the bridge, continues north to US 85, part of the Texas Highway Freight Network
Connection-to-Major Highways-MX: The Avenida Francisco Villa/Avenida Benito Juárez provides access to Calle Ignacio de la Peña/Calle 16 de Septiembre which connects with MEX 45.
InspectionFacility-BorderStation: The Paso del Norte land port of entry (LPOE) is owned by the United States and is under the jurisdiction, custody, and control of the U.S. General Services Administration (GSA). The facility was com_x0002_pleted in 1967, following the ratification of the Chamizal Treaty when the channel of the Rio Grande River was moved. The facility was renovated in 1990 and expanded in 2009.
ModeNotes: The number of lanes and hours of operation pertain to U.S. facilities. Toll rates are for 2-axle passenger vehicles.
DidYouKnow:
Paso del Norte Bridge 
had 3.5 million northbound pedestrian 
crossings in 2024—
the most at any 
Texas-Mexico border 
crossing.
Comments-BridgeDirector:
Comments on Factsheet:
Change Did you know? Paso del Norte Bridge had 3.5 million northbound pedestrian crossings in 2024 - the most at any Texas-Mexico border crossing.

Location:
El Paso, El Paso County, Texas, U.S. - Ciudad 
Juárez, Chihuahua, MX
AlternateNames: Stanton-Lerdo Bridge | Stanton Street Bridge | Friendship Bridge | Puente Internacional del Buen Vecino | Puente Ciudad Juárez-Stanton El Paso | Puente Internacional Lerdo-Stanton
Description:
GOOD NEIGHBOR BRIDGE WAS REBUILT (as part of the Chamizal Treaty) and opened to traffic in 1967. A Presidential permit was not issued since it was not required for bridges built before 1972. The bridge is 880 feet long with 
three southbound lanes dedicated to passenger vehicles and other non-commercial traffic, one northbound SENTRI lane, also known as a dedicated commuter lane (DCL) and one southbound pedestrian lane. The U.S. side is owned and operated by the City of El Paso while the Mexican side is owned and operated by the Government of Mexico and operated by Fideicomiso de Puentes Fronterizos de Chihuahua.
BridgeOpened: Bridge existed at location since 1896.  Current bridge was rebuilt and opened in 1967.
MexicanOperator: Fideicomiso de Puentes Fronterizos de Chihuahua
Connection-to-Major-Highways-US: Stanton Street is also designated as US 62 and provides access to US 85 which is part of the Texas Highway Freight Network.
Connection-to-Major Highways-MX: The bridge access road, Avenida Lerdo, provides access to Calle Ignacio de la Peña/Calle 16 de Septiembre which interconnects with MEX 45
InspectionFacility-BorderStation: The land port of entry (LPOE) is owned by the United States and under the jurisdiction, custody, and control of U.S. General Services Administration (GSA). It was completed in 1967 and expanded in 2014. GSA leases the northbound facilities from the City of El Paso.
ModeNotes: The number of lanes and hours of operation pertain to U.S. facilities. Toll rates are for 2-axle passenger vehicles.
DidYouKnow: Good Neighbor Bridge was the first bridge in El Paso with a dedicated commuter lane, opened to pre-enrolled northbound traffic in September 1999.
Comments-BridgeDirector:
Comments on Factsheet:
- In the region, “Good Neighbor Bridge” is considered an alternate name, but the location is commonly known as “Stanton Bridge.” You can remove “Good Neighbor Bridge” as the primary name and keep “Stanton Bridge” instead. “Good Neighbor Bridge” can remain listed as an alternate name.
- use the same font size for the subtitles for all  bridges
- Update the bridge name in the maps to Stanton Bridge; we can keep Good Neighbor Bridge in parentheses.
- Originally built in 1882, "it was the first pedestrian and vehicular bridge to span the Rio Grande". - El Paso Museum of History
- Change Mexican side to Mexico side
- Change Did you know to "Stanton Bridge was the first bridge in El Paso with a dedicated commuter lane, opened to pre-enrolled northbound traffic in September 1999."
Comments-UNT-or-TxDOT: 0109 Zaragoza-Ysleta, Lerdo-Stanton, Paso del Norte and Guadalupe-Tornillo Border Bridges – Mexico Projects

Location:
El Paso, El Paso County, Texas, U.S. – Ciudad 
Juárez, Chihuahua, MX
AlternateNames: BOTA | Bridge of the Americas– Córdova | Puente Internacional Córdova-De Las Américas | Puente Río Bravo | Cordova Bridge | Puente de las Américas | Puente Libre | Free Bridge
Description: ORIGINALLY BUILT IN 1967 as part of the Chamizal Treaty, Bridge of the Americas was replaced in 1998. The bridge is 506 feet long. Each direction of travel has four lanes of passenger vehicle traffic, two lanes of commercial truck traffic, and a pedestrian walkway. The U.S. side is owned and operated by the U.S. section of the International Boundary and Water Commission. The Mexican side is owned by the Mexican Government and operated by the Mexican section of the IBWC.
US-Owner: International Boundary and Water Commission (U.S. Section)
MexicanOperator: International Boundary and Water Commission (Mexico Section)
Connection-to-Major-Highways-US: The bridge lanes are also designated as I-110, which provides access to I-10, part of the National Highway Freight Network.
Connection-to-Major Highways-MX: The bridge lanes are also designated as MEX 45.
InspectionFacility-BorderStation: The Bridge of the Americas land port of entry (LPOE) is owned by the United States and under the jurisdiction, custody, and control of U.S. General Services Administration (GSA). The facility was completed in 1967 following ratification of the Chamizal Treaty. It was renovated in 2003 and is slated for a major modernization to be completed in 2031.
ModeNotes: The number of lanes and hours of operation pertain to U.S. facilities. Toll rates are for 2-axle passenger vehicles and 5-axle commercial trucks.
DidYouKnow: In 2024, Bridge of the Americas had the most northbound bus crossings in the El Paso region.
Comments-UNT-or-TxDOT: 0128 Cordova International Bridge – De las Américas – Mexico Projects

Location:
El Paso, El Paso County, Texas, U.S. – Ciudad 
Juárez, Chihuahua
AlternateNames: Zaragoza Bridge | Ysleta-Zaragoza Bridge | Puente Zaragoza | Puente Ysleta-Zaragoza
Description:
ORIGINALLY BUILT IN 1938, Ysleta Bridge was rebuilt in 1955 and then replaced with a pair of bridges in 1990. The current bridges are 804 feet long and opened to traffic in 1990. The first features four lanes accommodating commercial truck traffic (two southbound lanes, one standard northbound lane and one northbound FAST lane). The second is a five-lane bridge providing for passenger vehicles (two standard lanes in each direction, one northbound SENTRI lane, and one pedestrian walkway in each direction). The U.S. side is owned and operated by the City of El Paso. The Mexican side is owned by 
the Government of Mexico and operated by Fideicomiso de Puentes Fronterizos de Chihuahua.
MexicanOperator: Fideicomiso de Puentes Fronterizos de Chihuahua
Connection-to-Major-Highways-US:
The bridge access road 
is near Loop 375/Cesar Chavez Border Highway/Americas Avenue which connects to I-10, part of the National 
Highway Freight Network.
Connection-to-Major Highways-MX: The bridge is accessed by Avenida Waterfill and Prol. Manuel J. Clouhtier which are near Bulevar Inde_x0002_pendencia that connects with MEX 2 and continues to MEX 45.
InspectionFacility-BorderStation: The Ysleta land port of entry (LPOE) is owned by the United States and is under the jurisdiction, custody, and control of U.S. General Services Administration (GSA). It was built on 67 acres of land in 1991 and modernized in 2009.
ModeNotes: The number of lanes and hours of operation pertain to U.S. facilities. Toll rates are for 2-axle passenger vehicles and 5-axle commercial trucks.
DidYouKnow: In 2024, Ysleta Bridge had the most northbound commercial truck crossings in the El Paso region.

Comments on Factsheet:
- Change Ysleta Bridge to Ysleta-Zaragoza Bridge
- Change Puente International Zaragoza-Ysleta to Puente Internacional Zaragoza
- Change "special" clearance program to "pre-approved" clearance program
- Change Did you know? In 2024, Ysleta Bridge 
had the most northbound commercial truck crossings in 
the El Paso region.

Location: Fabens and Tornillo, El Paso County, Texas, U.S .– Caseta, Chihuahua, MX
AlternateNames: Tornillo-Guadalupe Bridge | Puente Internacional Tornillo-Guadalupe | Puente Internacional Reemplazo Guadalupe-Tornillo
Description: MARCELINO SERNA BRIDGE WAS BUILT IN 2014 and opened to traffic in 2014. A Presidential permit was issued in 2005. The bridge is 1,274 feet long and has three travel lanes in each direction: one for commercial truck traffic and two for passenger vehicles. There is a pedestrian walkway in each direction. The U.S. side is owned and operated by El Paso County. The Mexican side is owned by the Government of Mexico and operated by Fideicomiso de Puentes Fronterizos de Chihuahua.
MexicanOperator: Fideicomiso de Puentes Fronterizos de Chihuahua
Connection-to-Major-Highways-US:
M.F. Aguilera Road/FM 
3380 connects to Alameda Avenue/
TX 20 and I-10 which is on the National 
Highway Freight Network.
Connection-to-Major Highways-MX: The international bridge access road connects to MEX 2.
InspectionFacility-BorderStation: The Marcelino Serna land port of entry (LPOE) was constructed in 2014 to replace the Fabens-Caseta crossing. The facility includes non-intrusive inspection technologies. U.S. Customs & Border Protection (CBP) began processing northbound traffic at the Tornillo port of entry in November 2014.
ModeNotes: The number of lanes and hours of operation pertain to U.S. facilities. Toll rates are for 2-axle passenger vehicles and 5-axle commercial trucks.
DidYouKnow: Marcelino Serna Bridge is the longest international bridge in the El Paso region.

No comments on factsheet.

Description: FORT HANCOCK-EL PORVENIR BRIDGE WAS BUILT IN 1937.  Presidential permits were not required for bridges built before 1972. The bridge is 510 feet long and has one lane in each direction. The U.S. side is owned and operated by the U.S. section of the International Boundary and Water Commission (IBWC). The Mexican side is owned and operated by the Mexican section of the IBWC.

Location: Presidio, Presidio County, Texas, U.S. – Ojinaga, Chihuahua, MX
AlternateNames: Presidio Bridge | Puente Internacional Ojinaga-Presidio | Presidio-Ojinaga Bridge | Puente Ojinaga
Description: FIRST SPAN OF PRESIDIO-OJINAGA INTERNATIONAL BRIDGE OPENED TO TRAFFIC IN 1985. The Presidential permit was awarded in 1976 and amended in 1982. A second span was completed and opened to traffic in 2023. Both bridges are 791 feet long with two lanes and a pedestrian walkway. The U.S. side of the bridge is owned by the State of Texas and operated by the Texas Department of Transportation. The U.S. land port of entry (LPOE) is privately owned. The Mexican side is owned by the Government of Mexico and operated by Caminos y Puentes Federales de Ingresos y Servicios Conexos (CAPUFE).
BridgeOpened: First span of current bridge opened in 1985. Second span opened in 2023.
MexicanOperator: Caminos y Puentes Federales de Ingresos y Servicios Conexos (CAPUFE)
Connection-to-Major-Highways-US: The bridge access road interconnects with US 67 which is part of the Texas Highway Freight Network.
Connection-to-Major Highways-MX: The bridge access road provides a connection to MEX 16 and CHIH 67.
InspectionFacility-BorderStation: The Presidio land port of entry (LPOE) is leased by the United States and is under the control of U.S. General Services Administration (GSA) . It was completed in 2002. The LPOE is owned by RCS, Inc.
ModeNotes: The number of lanes and hours of operation pertain to U.S. facilities. Toll rates are for 2-axle passenger vehicles and 5-axle commercial trucks.
DidYouKnow: Presidio-Ojinaga International Bridge is the only non-rail international bridge owned by the State of Texas.
Comments-BridgeDirector:
No comments on factsheet.

Second span was opened for traffic at the Presidio-Ojinaga International Bridge in 2023
Presidio-Ojinaga International Bridge (first span) modernized/renovated/expanded or rebuilt/replaced - 2023 Converted to one way traffic (NB) with construction completed of the second bridge
Presidio-Ojinaga International Bridge (second span) modernized/renovated/expanded or rebuilt/replaced – Construction Completed 2023

Location: Big Bend National Park, Brewster County, Texas, U.S. – Boquillas del Carmen, Coahuila, MX
Description: ORIGINALLY AN INFORMAL AND UNCONTROLLED BORDER CROSSING, the Boquillas Crossing was closed in 2002 and reopened in 2013, when U.S. Customs & Border Protection (CBP) installed a virtual kiosk and document scanner to process northbound pedestrians. The border can be crossed on foot by fording the river (if the water depth permits) but most people crossing the border use a rowboat service to cross the Rio Grande. This service is provided by a commercial operator through an agreement with the National Park Service. The U.S. side of the crossing is within Big Bend National Park which is administered by the U.S. National Park Service. The Mexican side of the crossing is managed by the municipio of Boquillas del Carmen.
MexicanOperator: Owner Operated
Connection-to-Major-Highways-US: The crossing point is accessed by Boquillas Canyon Road within Big Bend National Park. This road provides access to Park Route 12, one of the main roads within the park.
Connection-to-Major Highways-MX: Boquillas Crossing is accessed by a local road to the town of Boquillas del Carmen. It is a short walk to the village or burros are available to ride. The Boquillas del Carmen community is connected to the interior of Mexico by MX 53.
ModeNotes: Rio Grande River can be crossed on foot (if water depth permits), but most people use rowboat service.
DidYouKnow: Boquillas Crossing is the only pedestrian-only crossing on the Texas-Mexico border.
Comments-BridgeDirector: All of the information on the attachment seems to be correct.  The border was closed after 9/11 and then reopened in the current building in 2013.  The actual building was built between 2012 and 2013.  The processing equipment has been upgraded over the last few years but the description is still accurate.  The prices for the boat ride are still valid.

Location:
Del Rio, Val Verde County, Texas, U.S. – Ciudad 
Acuña, Coahuila, MX
AlternateNames: Lake Amistad Dam International Crossing | Amistad Dam | La Presa Amistad | Cruce Internacional de la Amistad
Description:
LAKE AMISTAD DAM CROSSING WAS BUILT IN 1969. The U.S. side of the crossing is owned and operated by the U.S. section of the International 
Boundary and Water Commission. The Mexico side is owned and operated by the Mexican section of the International Boundary and Water Commission.
US-Owner: International Boundary and Water Commission (U.S. Section)
MexicanOwner: International Boundary and Water Commission (Mexican Section)
MexicanOperator: Owner Operated

Connection-to-Major Highways-MX: The bridge access road interconnects with MEX 2.
InspectionFacility-BorderStation: The land port of entry (LPOE) is owned by U.S. Customs & Border Protection (CBP), and was completed in 1969.
ModeNotes: The number of lanes and hours of operation pertain to U.S. facilities. Toll rates are for 2-axle passenger vehicles.
DidYouKnow: Lake Amistad Dam Crossing is the only crossing in the Laredo region that is for passenger vehicles only.

Location:
Del Rio, Val Verde County, Texas, U.S. – Ciudad 
Acuña, Coahuila, MX
AlternateNames: Del Rio–Ciudad Acuña International Bridge | Puente Acuña | Puente Ciudad Acuña-Ciudad Del Río | Puente Internacional Ciudad Acuña-Del Río
Description: ORIGINALLY BUILT IN 1930, Del Rio International Bridge was reconstructed in 1967 and in 1988. The current bridge opened in 1988. The bridge is a 2,035-foot-long, four-lane bridge with two pedestrian sidewalks. The U.S. side of the bridge is owned and operated by the City of Del Rio. The Mexican side of the bridge is owned by the Government of Mexico and operated by Caminos y Puentes Federales de Ingresos y Servicios Conexos (CAPUFE).
MexicanOperator: Caminos y Puentes Federales de Ingresos y Servicios Conexos (CAPUFE)
PortAccess-or-Egress-Road-MX: Lib. José de Las Fuentes/C. Gral. Bravo
Connection-to-Major-Highways-US: The bridge access road is designated US 277BU/Spur 239 and connects to US 90 which is on the Texas Highway Freight Network.
Connection-to-Major Highways-MX: The bridge access road leads to central Ciudad Acuña. Several major roads provide access to MEX 29 and MEX 2.
InspectionFacility-BorderStation: The Del Rio land port of entry (LPOE) is owned by the United States and is under the jurisdiction, custody, and control of the U.S. General Services Administration (GSA). The LPOE was built in 1960. It was updated and expanded in 1991, 1999, and 2009 with a new import dock and new adminis_x0002_tration and non-commercial facilities. The new Toll Plaza building was relocated and opened in October of 2017.
ModeNotes: The number of lanes and hours of operation pertain to U.S. facilities. Toll rates are for 2-axle passenger vehicles and 5-axle commercial trucks.
DidYouKnow: At 2,035 feet, Del Rio International Bridge is the longest bridge in the Laredo region.
Comments-BridgeDirector:
Information in factsheet correct
1)  Current Bridge opened for business in 1988.  The information you have from 1967 to 1988 is correct in your attached PDF.
2)  The new Toll Plaza building was relocated and opened in October of 2017.
3)  Mill overlay project is scheduled for July of 2025 on the bridge.

AlternateNames: Laredo North | Bridge IV | Laredo IV | World Trade International Bridge | Puente Nuevo Laredo III | Puente Internacional Comercio Mundial, Nuevo Laredo III | Puente Internacional Nuevo Laredo III | Puente del Comercio Mundial Nuevo Laredo III | Puente del Comercio Mundial
Description:
WORLD TRADE BRIDGE OPENED IN 2000. The Presidential permit for this bridge was approved in 1994. The bridge is 977 feet long and is only for 
commercial trucks. Four vehicle lanes cross the border in each direction. The U.S. side of the bridge is owned and operated by the City of Laredo. The Mexican side is owned by the Government of Mexico and operated by the Fideicomiso del Puente III.

Connection-to-Major Highways-MX: The bridge access road connects to MEX 2.
InspectionFacility-BorderStation: The World Trade Bridge land port of entry (LPOE) is owned by the United States and is under the jurisdiction, custody, and control of the U.S. General Services Administration (GSA). It became operational on April 15, 2000.

is the busiest

crossing on the

Bridge-ENG: Canadian Pacific Kansas City Laredo Railroad Bridge
Bridge-ESP: Puente Internacional Ferroviario Nuevo Laredo - Laredo Texas
Location:
Laredo, Webb County, Texas, U.S. – Nuevo 
Laredo, Tamaulipas, MX
Description:
ORIGINALLY BUILT IN 1920, this railroad port of entry is equipped with a high-energy system to conduct non-invasive inspection of railcars. 
Agencia Nacional de Aduanas de México (ANAM) has a building on the premises allowing for joint cargo inspections with U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP). Both the Union Pacific and Canadian Pacific Kansas City Laredo (CPKC) Railroads, which this bridge serves, have yards with secondary inspection areas. The U.S. side of the bridge is owned and operated by CPKC. The Mexican side is owned by the Government of Mexico and operated by CPKC de México. Construction of a second span was completed in December 2024 and opened in February 2025.
BridgeOpened: Originally built in 1920. Second span completed in 2024.
MexicanOperator: Canadian Pacific Kansas City de México
RailroadConnection-to-MajorCities:
IN THE U.S.: Corpus Christi, Texas and San Antonio, Texas
IN MEXICO: Monterrey, Nuevo León

Bridge-ENG: Gateway to the Americas Bridge (Laredo Bridge I)
Bridge-ESP: Puente Internacional Puerta de las Américas
Location:
Laredo, Webb County, Texas, U.S. – Nuevo 
Laredo, Tamaulipas, MX
AlternateNames: Convent Avenue Bridge | Laredo International Bridge | Bridge #1 | Old Bridge | Lare_x0002_do-Nuevo Laredo Bridge I | Laredo Convent Avenue Port of Entry | Gateway to the Americas International Bridge | Puente Internacional Puerta de las Américas Nuevo Laredo I | Puente Laredo I | Puente Viejo | Puente Nuevo Laredo
Description: GATEWAY TO THE AMERICAS BRIDGE WAS A PRIVATELY OWNED FACILITY that the City of Laredo purchased in 1946. After being destroyed by a flood in 1954, the City rebuilt it in 1956. The bridge is 1,050 feet long and accommodates two lanes of traffic and one pedestrian walkway in each direction. Northbound vehicle traffic is limited to passenger vehicles with drivers who are a member of the SENTRI trusted traveler program. The U.S. side of the bridge is owned and operated by the City of Laredo. The Mexican side of the bridge is owned by the Government of Mexico and operated by Caminos y Puentes Federales de Ingresos y Servicios Conexos (CAPUFE).
BridgeOpened: Purchased in 1946, destroyed in 1954, and reconstructed in 1956.
MexicanOperator: Caminos y Puentes Federales de Ingresos y Servicios Conexos (CAPUFE)
Connection-to-Major-Highways-US: The bridge access road, Convent Avenue, intersects with Matamoros Street and Houston Street that connect to I-35 which is part of the National Highway Freight Network and US 83 which is part of the Texas Highway Freight Network.
Connection-to-Major Highways-MX: The bridge access road, Avenida Vicente Guerrero, is also designated MEX 85.
InspectionFacility-BorderStation: The Gateway to the Americas Bridge land port of entry (LPOE) is owned by the United States and is under the jurisdiction, custody, and control of the U.S. General Services Administration (GSA). The border station was constructed in 1943. It was modernized and renovated in 1991 and 2018. The Administration Building is listed on the National Historic Registry.
ModeNotes: The number of lanes and hours of operation pertain to U.S. facilities. Toll rates are for 2-axle passenger vehicles.
DidYouKnow: In 2024, 69 percent of northbound pedestrian crossings in the Laredo region were at Gateway to the Americas Bridge.

No comments on factsheet - Referred to website
Built in 1954
Cannot confirm opening date -  (Kent Richard - Laredo; 08/20/2025 telephone call)
Year Bridge was modernized/renovated/expanded or rebuilt/replaced? New Office Admin Building was completed on December 2006

Bridge-ESP: Puente Internacional Juárez – Lincoln, Nuevo Laredo II
Location:
Laredo, Webb County, Texas, U.S. – Nuevo 
Laredo, Tamaulipas, MX
AlternateNames: Bridge II | Laredo – Nuevo Laredo Bridge II | Juárez-Lincoln Bridge | Laredo II | J&L | Puente Internacional Juárez – Lincoln Nuevo Laredo II | Puente 2 | Puente Nuevo | Puente Juárez – Lincoln | Puente Internacional Nuevo Laredo II (Juárez) – Lincoln
Description: JUÁREZ-LINCOLN INTERNATIONAL BRIDGE (Laredo Bridge II) IS 1,008 FEET LONG. It has four southbound lanes and four northbound lanes for non-commercial traffic. The bridge opened in 1976. The U.S. side of the bridge is owned and operated by the City of Laredo. The Mexican side of the bridge is owned by the Government of Mexico and operated by Caminos y Puentes Federales de Ingresos y Servicios Conexos (CAPUFE).
MexicanOperator: Caminos y Puentes Federales de Ingresos y Servicios Conexos (CAPUFE)
Connection-to-Major-Highways-US: The bridge access road feeds directly into the southern terminus of I-35 which is part of the National High_x0002_way Freight Network. It also connects to Houston Street/Matamoros Street which is also designated US 83. I-35 connects with US 59 and Loop 20 which are part of the Texas Highway Freight Network. US 83 connects with Loop 20 and SH 359.
Connection-to-Major Highways-MX: The bridge access road connects directly to Avenida Luis Donaldo Colosio, the loop around Nuevo Laredo. This highway provides access to MEX 2, MEX 85, and TAM 1.
InspectionFacility-BorderStation: The Juárez-Lincoln International Bridge land port of entry (LPOE) is owned by the United States and is under the jurisdiction, custody, and control of the U.S. General Services Administration (GSA). It was completed in 1982 and renovated in 2000 and 2018. In 2011, GSA completed a Customs & Border Protection (CBP)-funded project to add three additional primary inspections lanes for a total of 15 primary inspection lanes.
ModeNotes: The number of lanes and hours of operation pertain to U.S. facilities. Toll rates are for 2-axle passenger vehicles.
DidYouKnow: Juárez-Lincoln International Bridge had the most northbound passenger vehicle crossings in the Laredo region in 2024.

Bridge-ESP: Puente Internacional Presa Falcón - Falcón Heights
Location:
Falcon Heights, Starr County, Texas, U.S. - 
Ciudad Guerrero, Tamaulipas, MX
AlternateNames: Falcon Dam | Lake Falcon Dam Crossing | Puente Internacional Presa Falcón–Falcón Heights | Cruce Internacional Presa Falcón | Puente San Juan | Puente Internacional de la Presa | Bordo Interna_x0002_cional de la Presa
Description: BUILT AND OPENED IN 1960, this crossing is a two-lane road on top of Lake Falcon Dam. Presidential permits were not required for structures built before 1972. The U.S. side of the crossing is owned and operated by the U.S. section of the International Boundary and Water Commission (IBWC). The Mexican side is owned by the Mexican section of the IBWC.
BridgeOpened: Dam constructed in 1953. Border Station opened in 1960.
US-Owner: International Boundary and Water Commission (U.S. Section)
MexicanOwner: International Boundary and Water Commission (Mexican Section)
MexicanOperator: Owner Operated
Connection-to-Major-Highways-US: The bridge access road, FM 2098, connects to US 83 which is part of the Texas Highway Freight Network.
Connection-to-Major Highways-MX: The bridge access road provides access to MEX 2.
InspectionFacility-BorderStation: The land port of entry (LPOE) was constructed in 1953 by the IBWC. The building was expanded in 1977, 1989, and 2009. The border station was transferred from the IBWC to U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) after construction of the dam.
ModeNotes: The number of lanes and hours of operation pertain to U.S. facilities. Toll rates are for 2-axle passenger vehicles.
DidYouKnow: Lake Falcon Dam International Crossing is the only federally owned international bridge in the Rio Grande Valley region. The dam provides flood control and generates electricity.

Location:
Roma, Starr County, Texas, U.S. - Ciudad 
Miguel Alemán, Tamaulipas, MX
AlternateNames: Starr County International Bridge | Roma Bridge | Roma-Ciudad Miguel Alemán Bridge | Puente Internacional Miguel Alemán-Roma | Puente Roma-Miguel Alemán | Puente Miguel Alemán
Description: A TWO-LANE FACILITY, this bridge opened in 1978. This two-lane bridge is 810 feet long. The U.S. side of the bridge is owned and operated by Starr County. The Presidential permit for this facility was approved in 1977. The Mexican side is owned by the Government of Mexico and operated by Caminos y Puentes Federales de Ingresos y Servicios Conexos (CAPUFE).
MexicanOperator: Caminos y Puentes Federales de Ingresos y Servicios Conexos (CAPUFE)
PortAccess-or-Egress-Road-MX: C. Hidalgo/C. Zapata and C. Manuel Cavazos Lerma

Connection-to-Major Highways-MX: The bridge access road, Manuel Cavazos Lerma, connects to MEX 2.
InspectionFacility-BorderStation: The Roma land port of entry (LPOE) is leased by the United States and is under the control of the U.S. General Services Administration (GSA). It is owned by Starr County and was completed in 1989. An offsite secondary commercial inspection facility was opened in 2024.
ModeNotes: The number of lanes and hours of operation pertain to U.S. facilities. Toll rates are for 2-axle passenger vehicles and 5-axle commercial trucks.
DidYouKnow: The number one commodity that crossed Roma-Ciudad Miguel Alemán International Bridge in 2024—valued at $356 million—was edible vegetables and roots.

Location:

Description: OPENED IN 1966, the Starr-Camargo Bridge is a two-lane facility that is 591 feet long. Presidential permits were not required for structures built before 1972. The U.S. side is owned and operated by Starr-Camargo Bridge Company. The Mexican side is owned by the Government of Mexico and operated by Caminos y Puentes Federales de Ingresos y Servicios Conexos (CAPUFE).

Connection-to-Major Highways-MX: The bridge access road, interconnects with TAM 63 and connects to MEX 2.
InspectionFacility-BorderStation: The Rio Grande City land port of entry is leased by the United States and under the control of the General Services Administration and was constructed in 1966 and upgraded in 1991. It is owned by the Starr-Camargo Bridge Company.
ModeNotes: The number of lanes and hours of operation pertain to U.S. facilities. Toll rates are for 2-axle passenger vehicles and 5-axle commercial trucks.
DidYouKnow: The number one commodity, by value, that crossed Starr_x0002_Camargo Bridge in 2024 was mineral fuels, oils, and waxes.

Bridge-ESP: Cruce Internacional, “El Chalan” Díaz Ordáz-Los Ebanos
Location:
Los Ebanos, Hidalgo County, Texas, U.S. – 
Gustavo Díaz Ordaz, Tamaulipas, MX
AlternateNames: Los Ebanos – San Miguel Camargo | Ferry Gustavo Díaz Ordáz | Ferry Díaz Ordáz–Los Ebanos | Puente Internacional, “El Chalan” Diaz Ordáz Los Ebanos | El Chalan de Los Ebanos
Description:
ALTHOUGH A FERRY HAS OPERATED AT THIS CROSSING 
SINCE THE 1950s, the current ferry has been operating since 1979. The U.S. side of the ferry is owned and operated by the Reyna family. The Mexican side is owned and operated by Armando de la Garza.
MexicanOperator: Owner Operated
Connection-to-Major-Highways-US: The ferry crossing access road, Flores Street, leads into the town of Los Ebanos which is located south of US 83, which is part of the Texas Highway Freight Network.
Connection-to-Major Highways-MX: The ferry crossing access road, Adolfo López Mateos, leads into the town of Gustavo Díaz Ordáz, which is located north of MEX 2.
InspectionFacility-BorderStation: The land port of entry (LPOE) was completed in April 1992 and is owned by Customs and Border Protection (CBP). The land is owned by the ferry owner. This is one of three Texas border inspection facilities owned by CBP.
ModeNotes: The number of lanes and hours of operation pertain to U.S. facilities. Toll rates are for 2-axle passenger vehicles.
DidYouKnow: Los Ebanos Ferry is the only hand-drawn ferry on the US-Mexico border.

Location: Mission, Hidalgo County, Texas, U.S. – Reynosa, Tamaulipas, MX

Description:
ANZALDUAS INTERNATIONAL BRIDGE BEGAN OPERATIONS
IN 2009. It is a four-lane vehicular undivided bridge (two southbound lanes and two northbound lanes), which spans 3.3 miles. The Presidential permit for this facility was issued in 1999. The U.S. side is owned by the cities of Hidalgo, McAllen, Mission, and Granjeno and operated by the City of McAllen. The Mexican side is owned by the Government of Mexico and operated by Grupo Marhnos.
US-Owner: Cities of McAllen, Mission, Hidalgo, and Granjeno
MexicanOperator: Grupo Marhnos
Connection-to-Major-Highways-US: The bridge access road, FM 396/Anzalduas Highway, connects to FM 1016/East Military Road and I-2. Farther to the east, I-2 is a designated portion of the National Highway Freight Network.
Connection-to-Major Highways-MX: The bridge access road connects to MEX 40 which provides access to MEX 2.
InspectionFacility-BorderStation: The Anzalduas land port of entry (LPOE) opened in 2009.
ModeNotes: The number of lanes and hours of operation pertain to U.S. facilities. Toll rates are for 2-axle passenger vehicles and 5-axle commercial trucks.
DidYouKnow: At 3.3 miles, Anzalduas International Bridge is the longest bridge on the Texas-Mexico border.

Location: Hidalgo, Hidalgo County, Texas, U.S. – Reynosa, Tamaulipas, MX
AlternateNames: Hidalgo Bridge | McAllen-Hidalgo Bridge | McAllen-Hidalgo-Reynosa International Bridge | Puente Internacional Reynosa–Hidalgo | Puente Reynosa_x0002_Hidalgo I y II | Puente Reynosa | Puente Reynosa-McAllen I
Description: CONSISTING OF TWO STRUCTURES, the McAllen/Hidalgo International Bridge includes an older four-lane bridge, which is 524 feet long and was built in 1965. This bridge serves only southbound traffic. The newer four-lane bridge, which is 852 feet long and was built in 1987, serves only northbound traffic. This crossing also accommodates pedestrians. The Presidential permit for the second structure was issued in 1985. The U.S. side of the bridge is owned and operated by the City of McAllen. The Mexican side of the bridge is owned by the Government of Mexico and operated by Caminos y Puentes Federales de Ingresos y Servicios Conexos (CAPUFE).
BridgeOpened: Current bridge comprise older structure built in 1965 and newer structure built in 1987.
MexicanOperator: Caminos y Puentes Federales de Ingresos y Servicios Conexos (CAPUFE)

Connection-to-Major Highways-MX: The bridge access road, Luis Echeverría, connects with MEX 97 and connects to MEX 2 and MEX 40.
InspectionFacility-BorderStation: The Hidalgo land port of entry (LPOE) is leased by the United States and under the control of the U.S. General Services Administration (GSA). It was completed in 1982, and is owned by the City of McAllen.
ModeNotes: The number of lanes and hours of operation pertain to U.S. facilities. Toll rates are for 2-axle passenger vehicles.
DidYouKnow: McAllen/Hidalgo International Bridge is the number one bridge in the Rio Grande Valley region in 2024 for northbound pedestrian, passenger vehicle, and bus crossings.

The U.S. side of the bridge is owned and operated by the City of Pharr. and MEX 2D.

entry (LPOE) is owned by the United States and is under the jurisdiction, custody, and control of the U.S. General Services Administration (GSA). It opened to traffic in April 1996.

AN EIGHT-LANE PASSENGER VEHICLE BRIDGE, Donna-Rio Bravo International Bridge is approximately 1,000 feet long and 108 feet wide. It has four southbound and four northbound lanes. It was built in 2010 after receiving a Presidential permit in 1979. The U.S. side of the bridge

Puente y Autopistas S.A. De C.V. (COPA).

Location: Progreso, Hidalgo County, Texas, U.S. – Nuevo Progreso, Tamaulipas, MX
AlternateNames: B & P Bridge | Weslaco-Progreso International Bridge | Progreso-Nuevo Progreso International Bridge | Puente Las Flores | Puente Internacional Nuevo Progreso–Progreso
Description: OPENED IN 1952, Progreso International Bridge was rebuilt in 2003. It is a 628-foot long, four-lane automobile bridge with two lanes in each direction, plus pedestrian sidewalks. A separate two-lane truck bridge was built and opened to traffic in 2005. The U.S. side of the bridge is owned and operated by Progreso Bridge Company. The Mexican side is owned by the Government of Mexico and operated by Caminos y Puentes Federales de Ingresos y Servicios Conexos (CAPUFE).

Connection-to-Major Highways-MX: The bridge access road, Avenida Benito Juárez, connects to MEX 2D which provides access to MEX 2, MEX 97, and TAM 53.
InspectionFacility-BorderStation: The Progreso land port of entry (LPOE) is leased by the United States and under the control of the U.S. General Services Administration (GSA). GSA leases the LPOE facilities from the owner, Sam R. Sparks LP. The original border station facility was built in 1952 and renovated in 1983.
ModeNotes: The number of lanes and hours of operation pertain to U.S. facilities. Toll rates are for 2-axle passenger vehicles and 5-axle commercial trucks.
DidYouKnow: Progreso International Bridge is privately owned.

Connection-to-Major-Highways-US: The bridge access road, Mexico Boulevard, connects to Sam Perl Boulevard/East 12th Street/East 13th Street which connects to I- 69E which is on the National Highway Freight Network.
Connection-to-Major Highways-MX: The bridge access road, Las Americas Avenue, connects to Calle Cinco/Calle Sexta which provides access to MEX 2 and MEX 101.
InspectionFacility-BorderStation: The Brownsville and Matamoros land port of entry (LPOE) is owned by the United States and under the jurisdiction, custody, and control of the U.S. General Services Administration (GSA). It was completed in 1992
ModeNotes: The number of lanes and hours of operation pertain to U.S. facilities. Toll rates are for 2-axle passenger vehicles.
DidYouKnow: Brownsville & Matamoros Express Bridge is the only bridge on the Texas-Mexico border where both sides are owned and operated by the same entity.
Comments-BridgeDirector:
No comment on factsheet
1910: Operations began at the Brownsville and Matamoros Bridge Company.
1997: A new adjacent concrete bridge was constructed specifically for automobile traffic. The original bridge remained in use, but exclusively for rail traffic at that time.

Bridge-ESP: Puente Internacional Puerta México, Matamoros-Brownsville, (Puente Nuevo)
Location:
Brownsville, Cameron County, Texas, U.S. – 
Matamoros, Tamaulipas, MX
AlternateNames: New Bridge | Puente Internacional Puerta México | Puente Matamoros-Brownsville | Puente Nuevo | El Puente | Puente Internacional Matamoros-_x0002_Brownsville | Puente Internacional Nuevo | Puerta México | Puente Internacional Puerta
Description: ONE SPAN OF THE BRIDGE opened to traffic in 1969 and the other span opened to traffic in 1970. Each span of Gateway International Bridge accommodates two lanes. Presidential permits were not required for bridges built before 1972. The U.S. side of the bridge is owned by Cameron County and operated by Cameron County International Bridge System. The Mexican side is owned by the Government of Mexico and operated by Caminos y Puentes Federales de Ingresos y Servicios Conexos (CAPUFE).
BridgeOpened: First span of current bridge opened to traffic in 1969 and second span opened to traffic in 1970.
MexicanOperator: Caminos y Puentes Federales de Ingresos y Servicios Conexos (CAPUFE)
Connection-to-Major-Highways-US: The bridge access road, International Boulevard/SH 4, provides access to I-69E which is part of the National Highway Freight Network
Connection-to-Major Highways-MX: The bridge access road, Avenida Álvaro Obregón, connects to Calle Cinco/Calle Sexta which provides access to MEX 2 and MEX 101.
InspectionFacility-BorderStation: The Gateway International Bridge land port of entry (LPOE) is owned by the United States and under the jurisdiction, custody, and control of the U.S General Services Administration (GSA). It was constructed in 1926, renovated in 1990, and renovated and expanded in 1994. The LPOE is slated for modernization by 2028.
ModeNotes: The number of lanes and hours of operation pertain to U.S. facilities. Toll rates are for 2-axle passenger vehicles.
DidYouKnow: Gateway International Bridge had the second highest number of northbound pedestrians crossing in the Rio Grande Valley during 2024.
Comments-BridgeDirector:
No comment on factsheet.
Gateway International Bridge (first span) opened to traffic - 1969
Gateway International Bridge (second span) opened to traffic - 1970
Gateway International Bridge (first span) modernized/renovated/expanded - Pedestrian walkway renovated to include canopy in 2013
Gateway International Bridge (second span) modernized/renovated/expanded - Pedestrian walkway renovated to include canopy in 2013
Comments-UNT-or-TxDOT: 0528 Matamoros International Bridge – Mexico Projects

Bridge-ENG: Veterans International Bridge at Los Tomates
Bridge-ESP: Puente Internacional General Ignacio Zaragoza, Los Tomates, Matamoros-Brownsville
Location:
Brownsville, Cameron County, Texas, U.S. – 
Matamoros, Taumaulipas, MX
AlternateNames: Los Tomates Bridge | Brownsville Expressway Bridge | Expressway 77 Bridge | Veterans International Bridge | Puente Internacional General Ignacio Zaragoza | Puente Matamoros-Brownsville | Puente Los Tomates | Puente Internacional Matamoros III-Internacional Veteranos
Description: AT 4,024 FEET LONG, Veterans International Bridge at Los Tomates consists of two spans each with four-lanes. The Presidential permit for the southbound span was issued in 1993. The first span opened to traffic in 1999. The second span opened to traffic in 2013. The U.S. side of the bridge is owned by Cameron County and operated by Cameron County International Bridge System.  The Mexico side is owned by the Government of Mexico and operated by Compañía Contratista Nacional (CONOCAL).
BridgeOpened: First span opened in 1999 and second span opened in 2013.
MexicanOperator: Compañía Contratista Nacional (CONOCAL)
Connection-to-Major-Highways-US: The bridge access road is designated US 83 and connects with I-69E which is part of the National Highway Freight Network.
Connection-to-Major Highways-MX: The bridge access road, Cinco de Mayo, connects with Avenida Acción Cívica which connects to MEX 2.
InspectionFacility-BorderStation: The Los Tomates land port of entry (LPOE) is owned by the United States and is under the jurisdiction, custody, and control of the U.S. General Services Administration (GSA). It became operational on April 30, 1999.
ModeNotes: The number of lanes and hours of operation pertain to U.S. facilities. Toll rates are for 2-axle passenger vehicles and 5-axle commercial trucks.
DidYouKnow: Veterans International Bridge at Los Tomates is part of the Port of Brownsville Overweight Corridor.
Comments-BridgeDirector:
Comments on factsheet:
U.S. side is owned solely by Cameron County (The City of Brownsville has no ownership).  
Mexican side is currently operated by CONOCAL.
Under the  Inspection Lane section, please update the passenger vehicle lanes to 8 instead of 4.
Veterans International Bridge at Los Tomates (first span) opened to traffic - April 1999
Veterans International Bridge at Los Tomates (second span) opened to traffic - February 2013 (US side)  April 2014 (MX side)
Veterans International Bridge at Los Tomates (first span) modernized/renovated/expanded - remained in its present condition since 2014.
Veterans International Bridge at Los Tomates (second span) modernized/renovated/expanded - remained in its present condition since 2014.
Comments-UNT-or-TxDOT: 0353 Matamoros III International Bridge "Los Tomates" – Proyectos México
